items.title: Hebrew University develops color-tunable solar windows

featured_image.name: Revolutionizing Energy: 3D Printed Solar Panels

items.description: Researchers at the Hebrew University of Jerusalem have developed a semi-transparent, color-tunable solar cell that could transform windows and building facades into electricity generators without sacrificing aesthetics. The technology, announced this week, uses 3D-printed microscopic pillars to control light transmission while maintaining power output[1][2][3].

items.title: China rejects Japan appeal to lift export controls

featured_image.name: Japan says China's dual-use export ban 'unacceptable' | REUTERS

items.description:
Diplomatic and economic frictions between China and Japan intensified Friday as Beijing rejected Tokyo's appeals to lift export restrictions while Japanese officials confirmed widespread delays in agricultural shipments at Chinese customs, capping a week of mounting tensions between Asia's two largest economies.

Chinese Ambassador Wu Jianghao dismissed a Japanese Foreign Ministry petition Thursday to retract newly imposed export controls on dual-use items—products and technologies serving both civilian and military purposes—according to the Chinese embassy in Japan[1][2]. The restrictions, which China's Ministry of Commerce announced January 6 and implemented immediately, prohibit exports to Japan for military use or any purpose that could enhance Japanese military capabilities[3][4][5].

The measures came in direct response to comments by Japanese Prime Minister Sanae Takaichi, who suggested in November that Japan could intervene militarily if China used force against self-governed Taiwan, which Beijing claims as its territory[3][1][6]. Wu called China's actions "entirely legitimate, reasonable and lawful" and vital to national security[1][2].

items.title: China to end export tax rebates for solar, batteries

featured_image.name: China's overcapacity crackdown faces litmus test in solar sector

items.description:
China announced Thursday it will eliminate export tax rebates for solar products and phase out rebates for batteries, marking an escalation of Beijing's efforts to address overcapacity and ease international trade tensions in its clean energy sector.

The Ministry of Finance said value-added tax export rebates for photovoltaic products will be canceled starting April 1, 2026[1][2][3]. For battery products, the rebate rate will be reduced from 9% to 6% between April 1 and December 31, 2026, then eliminated entirely on January 1, 2027[1][2][3]. The announcement was made public on January 9, 2026, according to The Hindu BusinessLine[1].

The policy shift follows a previous reduction in December 2024, when the rebate rate for solar and battery products dropped from 13% to 9%[4][5]. China's dominant manufacturers—including JinkoSolar, LONGi, Trina Solar, and battery giants CATL and BYD—face increased export costs as the rebates disappear[6][7].

items.title: Grok AI limits image editing to paid users after deepfake scandal

featured_image.name: EU 'looking' into Grok's AI for sexually explicit childlike ... - Le Monde

items.description:
Elon Musk's social media platform X has limited Grok AI's image generation and editing capabilities to paying subscribers, a move that follows widespread criticism over the tool's use in creating sexualized deepfakes of women and children without consent[1][2][3][4]. As of Friday morning, users attempting to edit images through the chatbot receive a message stating that "image generation and editing are currently limited to paying subscribers"[3][4][5].

The restriction comes after governments in the UK, European Union, India, Malaysia, and France launched investigations into X and xAI, the company behind Grok, over concerns that the AI tool enabled the creation of illegal content[6][7][8][9]. UK Prime Minister Keir Starmer condemned the images as "disgraceful" and "disgusting," telling X to "get a grip" and pledging full government support for regulator Ofcom to take action[10][11][12].

items.title: Giant virus creates hidden chamber to hijack host cells

featured_image.name: Giant virus discovered in wastewater treatment plant infects ...

items.description:
Researchers from Kyoto University have discovered that a giant virus infecting amoebas creates a specialized subcellular environment to overcome a fundamental genetic incompatibility with its host, revealing a strategy that may be widespread among viral pathogens[1][2].

The study, published in Nature Microbiology, focused on Acanthamoeba polyphaga mimivirus, which possesses a genome with only 28% GC content while its amoeba host has 58% GC content[1][2]. This mismatch in codon usage should theoretically hinder viral protein production, yet the virus thrives.

items.title: Asian markets rise ahead of US jobs report

featured_image.name: JAPAN-ECONOMY

items.description:
Asian markets rose on Friday as investors braced for critical US jobs data and a potential Supreme Court decision that could reshape President Donald Trump's tariff policy.

Japan's Nikkei 225 surged 1.61% to close at 51,939.89, powered by a dramatic rally in Fast Retailing, the parent company of Uniqlo, which jumped 10.6% after reporting a 34% surge in quarterly operating profit and raising its annual earnings forecast[1][2]. Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index gained 0.3% to 26,231.79, while the Shanghai Composite rose 0.9% to 4,120.43[1]. South Korea's Kospi added 0.8%, though Australia's S&P/ASX 200 dipped slightly as Rio Tinto shares fell more than 6% following news of preliminary merger talks with Glencore[1].

items.title: Chemify says chemistry stuck in 'dark ages,' needs AI

featured_image.name: Chemistry is stuck in the dark ages – 'chemputation' can bring it into ...

items.description:
A Glasgow-based chemistry startup is pioneering a digital revolution in molecular synthesis, arguing that chemistry remains trapped in manual methods while other sciences have embraced automation and artificial intelligence.

In an article published Wednesday, Chemify founder and CEO Lee Cronin declared that "chemistry is stuck in the dark ages" and needs a programmable language to bring it into the digital era[1][2][3]. The University of Glasgow professor argues that while AI can design thousands of hypothetical drug molecules overnight, each still requires human chemists to manually synthesize them—creating a bottleneck that prevents chemistry from matching the speed of computational design[1][2].

items.title: Astronomers discover hottest early galaxy cluster, starless dark matter cloud

featured_image.name: Scientists Discover Cloud-9, a Starless 'Galaxy That Wasn't'

items.description:
Two extraordinary discoveries presented this week at the American Astronomical Society meeting in Phoenix are challenging fundamental assumptions about galaxy formation and the nature of dark matter, offering astronomers rare glimpses into the universe's earliest epochs.

Researchers announced the identification of the earliest and hottest galaxy cluster ever observed, alongside the first confirmed detection of a starless dark matter cloud—a "failed galaxy" that has existed unchanged for billions of years[1][2][3].

items.title: Oceans set heat record in 2025 for ninth straight year

featured_image.name: The Ocean: Guardian of Global Warming

items.description:
Earth's oceans absorbed a record-breaking amount of heat in 2025, marking the ninth consecutive year of unprecedented warming and intensifying concerns about extreme weather, rising seas, and collapsing marine ecosystems, according to research published Friday by an international team of scientists.

The upper 2,000 meters of the world's oceans absorbed 23 zettajoules more energy than in 2024—an amount equivalent to roughly 37 years of global energy consumption—according to the study in Advances in Atmospheric Sciences[1][2][3][4][5]. The research involved more than 50 scientists from 31 institutions across three continents[3][4].

"Every year, we are witnessing an increase in global temperatures—setting new records has become a recurring theme," said Prof. John Abraham from the University of St. Thomas, who co-authored the study[2]. "Global warming equates to ocean warming. To understand how much the Earth has warmed or how quickly we may warm in the future, we must look to the oceans"[2].

items.title: Oil prices climb on Venezuela, Iran supply concerns

featured_image.name: Oil prices rise over 3% as market focuses on Venezuela, supply ...

items.description:
Oil prices climbed for a second consecutive day Friday as traders weighed potential supply disruptions from Venezuela and escalating unrest in Iran, pushing Brent crude to $62.43 per barrel and West Texas Intermediate to $58.15[1][2][3].

The gains followed a sharp rally Thursday when both benchmarks surged more than 3%—the largest single-day increase since October—after two days of declines[1][2][4]. Brent is on track to climb 2.7% for the week, while WTI has gained 1.4%[1][2].

items.title: Ancient humans may have met at Indonesian cave 40,000 years ago

featured_image.name: Humans and ancient hominins shared Indonesian cave - New Atlas

items.description:
A deep excavation in Indonesia has uncovered evidence that modern humans and an extinct hominin species may have overlapped at the same cave site more than 40,000 years ago, according to research published Wednesday by an international archaeological team led by Griffith University.

The findings from Leang Bulu Bettue, a limestone cave in southern Sulawesi, reveal a dramatic shift in the archaeological record around 40,000 years ago that researchers believe marks the arrival of Homo sapiens and the possible replacement of archaic hominins who had occupied the island for over a million years[1][2][3][4].

"The depth and continuity of the cultural sequence at Leang Bulu Bettue now positions this cave as a flagship site for investigating whether these two human lineages overlapped in time," said Basran Burhan, a Griffith PhD candidate who led the study published in PLOS ONE[2][4].

items.title: Interstellar comet 3I/ATLAS puzzles scientists with three symmetrical jets

featured_image.name: Interstellar comet 3I/ATLAS shines in new image captured ...

items.description:
As the rare interstellar visitor 3I/ATLAS speeds through our solar system on its way toward Jupiter, astronomers have detected an unusual feature that has moved the scientific conversation from curiosity to genuine puzzle: the ancient comet is producing three perfectly symmetrical jets of material, separated by a strikingly consistent 120 degrees.

The phenomenon, confirmed through observations by NASA's Hubble Space Telescope and the Gemini North telescope in Hawaii between late November and late December 2025, defies standard models of how comets behave[1][2]. While most comets vent gas and dust in irregular, flickering plumes as they are heated by the sun, 3I/ATLAS has maintained this geometric precision for weeks, with each jet displaying comparable brightness and curvature[1][3].

items.title: Russian missiles kill one, wound 24 in Zelenskyy's hometown

featured_image.name: Ukraine Says Russia Launched Another Large Round of ...

items.description:
Two Russian Iskander ballistic missiles struck residential apartment buildings in Kryvyi Rih on Thursday evening, killing at least one person and wounding 24 others, including six children, in President Volodymyr Zelenskyy's hometown. The attack came as Russia continued its systematic targeting of Ukraine's energy infrastructure, leaving hundreds of thousands without power, water, and heating amid freezing temperatures[1][2][3][4].

The missiles hit the city around 5 p.m. local time, damaging approximately 15 apartment buildings and nearby vehicles[5][6][7]. Among the casualties was a 77-year-old woman who died in the strike, while the wounded included children aged 7 and 16[8][9]. One man who lost a leg in the explosion remained in critical condition and underwent surgery[5][8].

items.title: Cambodia pushes back on Thai claims over border scam centers

featured_image.name: Cambodia Pushes Back on Thai Scam Strikes, Seeks to Cool ...

items.description:
Cambodia's Deputy Prime Minister Sun Chanthol said on Wednesday his country wants to "lower the temperature" with Thailand and pushed back against Bangkok's claims that recent border clashes were focused on combating scam centers, as both nations work to maintain a fragile 11-day-old ceasefire[1].

The comments come after Thailand and Cambodia signed a renewed ceasefire agreement on December 27, ending three weeks of fighting that killed at least 101 people and displaced more than half a million on both sides of the border[2][3]. Thailand released 18 Cambodian soldiers on December 31 who had been held as prisoners of war for 155 days, a move described by Thailand's Ministry of Foreign Affairs as "a gesture of goodwill and trust-building"[2].

items.title: Kim pledges unconditional, permanent support for Putin

featured_image.name: N Korea, Russia bound in 'blood' of war, Kim tells Putin in New Year ...

items.description:
North Korean leader Kim Jong Un has promised Russian President Vladimir Putin unconditional and permanent support for all his policies, according to a letter reported by state media KCNA on Friday[1][2][3][4][5].

"I will unconditionally respect and unconditionally support all your policies and decisions and I have a willingness to be always with you for the sake of you and your Russia," Kim wrote to Putin[1][2][5]. "This choice will be constant and permanent."

The letter, which KCNA said was a response to an earlier message from Putin, marks the latest expression of deepening ties between the two nations as North Korea provides critical military support to Russia's war in Ukraine[1][2][3][5].

items.title: Trump warns Iran over protester deaths as internet blackout spreads

featured_image.name: President Trump Speaks At The House GOP Member Retreat

items.description:
US President Donald Trump issued stark warnings to Iran on Thursday that Washington would respond with force if authorities continue killing peaceful protesters, as the Islamic Republic plunged into a nationwide internet blackout amid the largest demonstrations in more than three years.

Speaking with conservative radio host Hugh Hewitt on January 8, Trump declared that Iranian authorities would "have to pay hell" if they persist in lethal violence against demonstrators[1][2][3]. "I have let them know that if they start killing people, which they tend to do during their riots—they have lots of riots—if they do it, we are going to hit them very hard," Trump stated[2]. The warning came as human rights groups reported at least 39 to 45 protesters have been killed since demonstrations erupted in late December, including eight minors[4][5][6][7].

The protests, which began December 28 at Tehran's Grand Bazaar over economic grievances, have spread to all 31 provinces[4][8]. Violence intensified on Thursday evening after exiled Crown Prince Reza Pahlavi called for coordinated demonstrations at 8 p.m. local time[9][5]. Witnesses reported crowds chanting "Death to the dictator" and "Pahlavi will return" across Tehran and other major cities[9][5].

items.title: Chinese scientists extract 98% of gold from e-waste in 20 minutes

featured_image.name: Breakthrough composite boosts gold recovery from e-waste by 10x

items.description:
Researchers from China have developed a rapid and environmentally-friendly technique to extract more than 98 percent of gold from electronic waste in under 20 minutes, offering a potentially lucrative solution to the global e-waste crisis as gold prices hover near record highs.

The breakthrough method, developed by scientists at the Guangzhou Institute of Energy Conversion, part of the Chinese Academy of Sciences, and South China University of Technology, uses a simple chemical solution that operates at room temperature without the need for toxic substances like cyanide[1][2][3]. The findings were published in the journal Angewandte Chemie International Edition[1][4][3].

items.title: UN says US must pay dues despite Trump order to quit 66 groups

featured_image.name: Trump withdraws US from 66 international organizations – DW ...

items.description:
The United Nations said Thursday the United States has a legal obligation to continue funding U.N. agencies, one day after President Donald Trump signed an order withdrawing from 66 international organizations, including 31 affiliated with the world body[1][2][3].

Secretary-General Antonio Guterres expressed regret over the decision and stressed that assessed contributions to the U.N. regular budget and peacekeeping operations "are a legal obligation under the UN Charter for all Member States, including the United States," according to spokesman Stephane Dujarric[1][4][5]. The statement came as U.N. officials said they learned of the withdrawal through news reports and White House social media posts Wednesday, with no formal notification from the Trump administration[1][2].

The executive order, which followed a yearlong review, targets organizations the White House says promote "radical climate policies, global governance, and ideological programs that conflict with U.S. sovereignty and economic strength"[6][7][8]. Among the 31 U.N. entities are the U.N. Population Fund, which provides reproductive health services in more than 150 countries, and UN Women, which promotes gender equality[1][2][9]. The order also directs withdrawal from the U.N. Framework Convention on Climate Change, the 1992 treaty that underpins the Paris climate agreement[6][1][2].

Secretary of State Marco Rubio defended the move in a statement, saying the Trump administration determined the organizations were "redundant, mismanaged, unnecessary, wasteful, poorly run" or advancing agendas inconsistent with U.S. interests[10][11][12]. The White House said the withdrawals would end American taxpayer funding for entities "that advance globalist agendas over U.S. priorities"[6][13][9].

items.title: Chinese study finds urban air contains millions of microplastic particles per cubic meter

featured_image.name: Scientists detect hidden plastic clouds hovering over Chinese cities

items.description:
Researchers in China have identified urban atmospheres as primary reservoirs for microplastic and nanoplastic pollution, finding concentrations up to a million times higher than previously detected using traditional methods.

A study published in Science Advances on January 7 by scientists from the Institute of Earth Environment of the Chinese Academy of Sciences revealed that microplastics and nanoplastics accumulate in city air at levels ranging from 140,000 to 180,000 particles per cubic meter in the two Chinese megacities of Guangzhou and Xi'an[1][2][3]. The research marks the first detection of nanoplastics as small as 200 nanometers in complex environmental samples[4][1][2].

items.title: Iran protest death toll hits 45 as internet blackout imposed

featured_image.name: Protests Spread in Iran, and Crackdowns Escalate

items.description:
At least 45 protesters, including eight minors, have been killed during 12 days of nationwide demonstrations in Iran, with Wednesday marking the deadliest single day of unrest as security forces killed 13 people, according to Norway-based Iran Human Rights[1]. The protests, which began in Tehran's Grand Bazaar on December 28 over economic grievances, have now spread to all 31 of Iran's provinces and evolved into broader calls for regime change[2][1].

Internet monitoring group NetBlocks reported a nationwide internet blackout on Thursday as authorities intensified efforts to suppress the demonstrations[3][4]. "The evidence shows that the scope of crackdown is becoming more violent and more extensive every day," said Iran Human Rights director Mahmood Amiry-Moghaddam, adding that hundreds more have been wounded and over 2,000 arrested[1].
